did.unittitle: Edouard Roditi papers

physdesc.extent: (174 boxes, 12 oversize boxes, and 1 oversize folder)

did.abstract: Edouard Roditi (1910-1992) was a surrealist author and poet. He published the first Surrealist manifesto in English, "The new reality," in the Oxford outlook (1929). While continuing his literary interests, he worked for the U.S. government during World War II for the Office of War Information and also served as an interpreter for the State Department during the San Francisco conference which established the United Nations. His published books include Poems for F (1934), Oscar Wilde: a critical study (1947), Dialogues on art (1960), De l'homosexualité (1962), In a lost world (1978), and Thrice chosen (1981). Roditi also held teaching positions at various colleges and universities. The collection consists of material related to Roditi's life and career. Includes correspondence, original and photocopied manuscripts by Roditi and others, books, periodicals and other printed items by or about Roditi, documents, awards, photographs, memorabilia, and letters regarding family history and biographical information, and books from his library, including many inscribed by artists and writers.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.
Letters by T.S. Eliot cannot be copied except with the permission of Mrs. T.S. Eliot.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Edouard Roditi Papers (Collection 644). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by UCLA Library Special Collections staff.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Édouard Roditi was born in Paris, June 6, 1910; he was educated in England at Elstree, Charterhouse, and Balliol, and received a BA from the University of Chicago; he became acquainted with T.S. Eliot, James Joyce, André Breton and other leading literary figures, while living in London, Paris, and Berlin (1929-37); he published the first Surrealist manifesto in English, "The new reality," in the Oxford outlook (1929); while continuing his literary interests, he worked for the U.S. government during World War II for the Office of War Information and also served as an interpreter for the State Department during the San Francisco conference which established the United Nations; published books include Poems for F (1934), Oscar Wilde: a critical study (1947), Dialogues on art (1960), De l'homosexualité (1962), In a lost world (1978), and Thrice chosen (1981); Roditi also held teaching positions at various colleges and universities; in addition to his literary achievements, Roditi was known as a generous and encouraging mentor to young writers; he died in Spain on May 10, 1992.

chronitem.event: Born 6 June, Paris
Attended Elstree School, Elstree, Herts, England
Attended Charterhouse, Godalming, England
Attended Balliol College, Oxford
Partner in Editions du Sagittaire, publisher of early Surrealists
In print at age 18, English translation of poems by Leon Paul Fargue published in Transition
Published first Surrealist manifesto in English, "The New Reality," in the Oxford Outlook.
First visited the United States at age 19
Lived in London, Paris, Berlin
Roditi's poems published in Criterion
Poems For F published
A.B. University of Chicago
Fellowship, University of California, Berkeley
Teacher, University of Kansas City, Missouri
Prison Within Prison: Three Hebrew Elegies published
Began work for the U.S. Government, Office of War Information, Radio Division
Pieces Of Three published
Interpreter for U.S. Department of State, San Francisco Conference, establishing the United Nations
Edited Das Lot, with Alain Bosquet and Alexander Koval
Interpreter, Nuremburg International Military Tribunal
Oscar Wilde: A Critical Study published
Reports Officer & Governmental Administrator, Office of Military Government for Germany of the U.S.
Poems 1928-1949 published
Dismissed as alleged security risk by U.S. Government
Established Paris residence
Expelled from France for two years as an alleged security risk, expulsion order rescinded in 1960.
Dialogues On Art published
ER's English translation of Yashar Kemal's Memed, My Hawk published
De L'homosexualite published
Les Plus Belles Lettres D'eugene Delacroix selected, edited and published by ER
Visiting professor, San Francisco State College. Anne Rice was one of his students.
New Hieroglyphic Tales: Prose Poems published
Visiting professor, University of California, Santa Cruz
Magellan Of The Pacific published
Emperor Of Midnight published
The Disorderly Poet published
Meetings With Conrad published, The Delights Of Turkey published
In A Lost World published
Thrice Chosen published, The Confessions Of A Saint published
New Old & New Testaments published
Etre Un Autre published
More Dialogues On Art published
ER's French translation of Horace Walpole's Hieroglyphic Tales published
ER's English translation of The Wandering Fool, poems by 13th century Turkish Dervish Gurus, published
Professor, Bard College, Annandale on Hudson
Oscar Wilde reprinted
Regents' Lecturer, University of California, Los Angeles
Choose Your Own World published
Died on May 10 in Cadiz, Spain

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of material related to the life and career of surrealist author and poet Édouard Roditi. Includes correspondence, original and photocopied manuscripts by Roditi and others, books, periodicals and other printed items by or about Roditi, documents, awards, photographs, memorabilia, and letters regarding family history and biographical information, and books from his library, including many inscribed by artists and writers. Contains correspondence with various artists and literary figures including W.H. Auden, Paul Bowles, T.S. Eliot, Christopher Isherwood, Josef Herman, Ned Rorem, and Oskar Tauschinski. Also includes corrections made by Eliot to early poems ca. 1928-30 written by Roditi.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Correspondence.
Manuscripts by Édouard Roditi and others.
Printed material by or about Édouard Roditi.
Biographical and personal material.
Books from the library of Édouard Roditi.
